In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  


You can read the [full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/mckool-raises/2/)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# New Study: GCs Have Brought The Majority Of Work In-House
## Clients have figured out they don't need lawyers. We're all doomed.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 1, 2017 at 2:30 PMNovember 1, 2017 at 1:29 PM
34
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/new-study-gcs-have-brought-the-majority-of-work-in-house/&text=New%20Study:%20GCs%20Have%20Brought%20The%20Majority%20Of%20Work%20In-House)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/new-study-gcs-have-brought-the-majority-of-work-in-house/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/new-study-gcs-have-brought-the-majority-of-work-in-house/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Clients are taking back that billable work.

More bad news for outside counsel.

Every quarter we report on the growing gap between the elite Biglaw firms and the rest of the Am Law 200. The outlook for law firms generally remains tepid, but the cream of the crop seem to keep chugging along while the rest increasingly stagnate. Well, if you’ve been looking to connect the dots, that [persistent slowing of demand for legal services](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/top-firms-build-bigger-gap-over-the-field-like-they-do-every-quarter/), here’s your culprit:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
51% of in-house legal teams report that more than half of their legal activities are now conducted internally. The biggest challenge in-house legal teams are trying to solve by bringing more legal services in-house is controlling costs, followed by completing tasks efficiently.

The [2017 In-House Legal Benchmarking Report](https://www.exterro.com/in-house-legal-benchmarking-report-2017/) from Exterro polled a number of in-house legal personnel about their business and found that everyone’s bringing more and more under the company tent as we’ve suspected for some time. And they’re doing it for the most obvious reason of all:

When asked why they brought more work in-house, they most frequently responded that it was because they could (they had built or expanded internal capacity and now were using it), to save money, or because better software had become available.

Because I can! Perhaps this could be phrased better than invoking the go to excuse of a toddlercaught reaching into a cookie jar, but this is a serious reason that spells trouble for Biglaw. While lawyers worry about AI building robot lawyers to displace attorneys — a fear that’s mostly overblown — the real technological threat to Biglaw is in easing once formidable legal processes to the point that in-house departments present a more cost-effective option than outsourcing. Legal holds and other document preservation tasks can be handled cheaper and more cost-effectively than ever by clients with the right tools. With clients reporting that they’ll be investing in more software solutions going forward, this inward flow of work shows no signs of stopping.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Where does that leave the outside counsel landscape?

And we suspect the likely outside winners will fit into two broad categories: those who can deliver standardized services efficiently, effectively, and at a very low cost, or at least lower than can be achieved internally; and those who deliver custom and specialized services — bespoke services — that only the rare corporation is likely to invest in developing itself.

Exactly what we’ve been seeing. The bigger, badder behemoths that can churn out work product and the elite brands that boast unique legal talent (or at least that clients believe to be unmatched) are winning the day. That obviously means that the top Am Law 200 firms see steady success, but it also presents a tremendous opportunity for small law firms, especially niche boutique firms, that can offer the bespoke services clients want without wasting money on the assembly line tasks that technology can move in-house. All the while, the rest of Biglaw starts to lose out on the grunt work that once covered the overhead.

At least there’s some good news for Biglaw:

Even though corporations seem to be bringing more work inside, they report moderate to strong satisfaction with the quality of outsourced legal work done for them. Twenty-one percent of respondents replied that they were “very satisfied” and another 48% said they were “somewhat satisfied.” Only 7% reporting being “somewhat dissatisfied,” and a slim 1% answered that they were “very dissatisfied.” When asked how providers of outsourced legal services could improve, corporations’ most frequent comments were that they could be less expensive and more responsive.

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Well that’s nice. But somehow I think that 21 percent of satisfaction isn’t going to pay the bills for very long.

Check out the [full report here](https://www.exterro.com/in-house-legal-benchmarking-report-2017/) for more insights into exactly how in-house counsel are using their resources.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is an editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. # Am Law 100 Firm Cuts Salaries, Eliminates Discretionary Bonuses
## The Biglaw firm emphasized the shared burden of weathering the COVID-19 financial storm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 10, 2020 at 5:07 PMApril 11, 2020 at 12:55 AM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/mintz-levin-cuts/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Cuts%20Salaries,%20Eliminates%20Discretionary%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/mintz-levin-cuts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/mintz-levin-cuts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Just because it’s Friday doesn’t mean the Biglaw austerity measures have taken a break. After all, time is meaningless in a quarantine, so let’s just pile on with the COVID-19 cost-cutting measures, Friday (Zoom) happy hour be damned.

Anyway, the latest firm that’s looking to control their expenses as the coronavirus-inspired economic decline rages on is Mintz Levin. The firm — one that takes the [87th place](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=212&name=Mintz-Levin) in the latest Am Law 200 ranking — announced a series of reductions that all employees will face. Managing partner Robert Bodian said in the email ([available in full on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/mintz-levin-cuts/2/)) that the firm’s priority is to maintain the health of the firm and keep everyone employed, but “[e]veryone will make some sacrifices.” The specific cuts vary on the employee’s position:

Associates, Of Counsel, Special Counsel and Practice Group Associates:
10% base pay cut.
No discretionary bonus (which would have been paid in June).
On-Track Associate and Of Counsel hours bonus will be paid in full.
Health insurance premium co-shares will not change.
No layoffs or furloughs (beyond ordinary course) are currently anticipated.

Patent Agents and Technical Specialists:
5% base pay cut.
No discretionary bonus (which would have been paid in June).
Health insurance premium co-shares will not change.
No layoffs or furloughs (beyond ordinary course) are currently anticipated.

Professional Staff:
5% base pay cut, subject to not falling below a $75k floor.
Base pay freeze – i.e., no merit or other increases this spring.
Overall discretionary bonus pool will be reduced by 50%.
Health insurance premium co-shares will not change.
The 401(k) match will be made for March but thereafter suspended.
No layoffs or furloughs (beyond ordinary course) are currently anticipated.

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
The partners are also shouldering their share of the financial burden. In a separate email ([available in full on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/mintz-levin-cuts/2/)), Bodian shared that among the steps taken to reduce costs is increasing the equity partner holdback to 40 percent, and reducing partner draws by 5-10 percent.

Hopefully these measures mean no other cuts will be needed at Mintz Levin.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Biglaw Firm Closes Office After COVID Outbreak
## Biglaw has to react to the omnicron variant.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 23, 2021 at 10:01 AMMarch 24, 2022 at 11:20 AM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/biglaw-firm-closes-office-after-covid-outbreak/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Closes%20Office%20After%20COVID%20Outbreak)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/biglaw-firm-closes-office-after-covid-outbreak/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/biglaw-firm-closes-office-after-covid-outbreak/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s a sign of the times… the omicron variant of COVID-19 is rearing its ugly head in pretty much every facet of life, and that includes Biglaw.

The uber-catchy variant of the coronavirus is making its way through, well, pretty much everyone, and ruining holiday plans in the process. And Biglaw firms are being forced to respond when their employees are stricken with the virus. At Fenwick, employees in not one, not two, but three different cities have tested positive for COVID. And in the New York office, some of the folks with the ‘Vid were in the office or in close contact with colleagues. As a result, the firm is closing the offices until at  least January 9th. You can read the firm’s email about the development below.

What has your firm announced as far as a revised reopening plan is concerned now that the omicron variant has arrived? The more information is out there, the more likely it is that firms will be able to establish a new market standard for a return.

As soon as you find out about reopening plans at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.



Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# This Top 30 Biglaw Firm Expects Lawyers To Work From The Office 'By Default'
## Lawyers really aren't happy about this.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 1, 2021 at 12:14 PMJune 2, 2021 at 11:07 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/paul-hastings-reopening/&text=This%20Top%2030%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Expects%20Lawyers%20To%20Work%20From%20The%20Office%20‘By%20Default’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/paul-hastings-reopening/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/paul-hastings-reopening/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With the unofficial start of summer now firmly in the rearview window, many Biglaw firms have already announced their return-to-office plans. While the majority of firms have leaned into the necessity of flexible work arrangements in a post-pandemic world, some are still hanging on to memories of the old days, where lawyers and staff members were expected to be at their desks, all day, every day, if possible. It seems like Paul Hastings — ranked at No. 27 on the most recent Am Law 100 with a 2020 gross revenue of $1,310,126,000 — is a firm that may fall into the latter category.

According to a memo sent late last week by chairman Seth Zachary and co-managing partners Greg Nitzkowski and Ronan O’Sullivan, the firm is encouraging all employees to find some time to voluntarily reacquaint themselves with office life this summer, because come September, it looks like office life will no longer be voluntary. Here’s an excerpt from that memo (emphasis added):

Beginning Tuesday, Sept. 7, all team members – both attorneys and staff – should be working from the office. We understand and respect the flexibility that individual circumstances will require. But, by default, we should work from the office when we are able. This return to office is as important for helping to nurture and strengthen our sense of culture, teamwork and collaboration as it is for serving clients at the highest levels.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
While Paul Hastings isn’t specifically mandating a full-time return, how are people taking the news of being back in the office, “by default”? Not well. One of our sources had this to say about the firm’s plans: “I’m sure many of my colleagues will literally be giving notice with this as the stated reason.” Yikes.

Is the bark on this messaging worse than its bite? As noted by Zachary, Nitzkowski, and O’Sullivan, the firm “understand[s] and respect[s] the flexibility that individual circumstances will require.” If that’s the case, and some form of remote work is still on table at Paul Hastings, then perhaps there was a kinder, gentler way to communicate the firm’s back-to-office plans in a more effective way.

We’ve reached out to the firm for comment, but have yet to hear back.

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Paul Hastings.)

What has your firm announced as far as a reopening plan is concerned? The more information is out there, the more likely it is that firms will be able to establish a market standard for a return to work.

As soon as you find out about the reopening plan at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. text:
[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Wednesday, December 14, 2016
“No foul on spouse’s secret e-mail forwarding”: In April 2015, Patricia Manson of the Chicago Daily Law Bulletin had [an article](http://www.chicagolawbulletin.com/Archives/2015/04/22/E-mail-Wiretap-Act-04-22-15.aspx) that begins, “A man who alleges his estranged wife secretly forwarded his e-mails to her e-mail account does not have a case under the Wiretap Act, a federal judge has ruled.”

Today, a unanimous three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit](http://www.ca7.uscourts.gov) — in [an opinion](http://media.ca7.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/rssExec.pl?Submit=Display&Path=Y2016/D12-14/C:15-2076:J:Sykes:aut:T:fnOp:N:1879107:S:0) written by Circuit Judge [Diane S. Sykes](http://www.fjc.gov/servlet/nGetInfo?jid=3074&cid=999&ctype=na&instate=na) — reinstated the husband’s Wiretap Act claim against his estranged wife.

Posted at [11:04 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69809) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Senator Menendez’s cert petition unloads on the Third Circuit”: Matthew Stiegler has [this post](http://thirdcircuitblog.com/writing/senator-menendezs-cert-petition-unloads-on-the-third-circuit/) today at his “CA3blog.”

Posted at [10:17 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69808) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Justices to Hear Cases on Withheld Evidence and Bad Advice”: Adam Liptak will have [this article](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/14/us/politics/justices-to-hear-cases-on-withheld-evidence-and-bad-advice.html) in Thursday’s edition of The New York Times.

Richard Wolf of USA Today reports that “[Supreme Court reopens decades-old D.C. murder](http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2016/12/14/supreme-court-reopens-decades-old-dc-murder/95444978/).”

Keith L. Alexander of The Washington Post reports that “[Supreme Court agrees to hear arguments in horrific 1984 D.C. murder case](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/supreme-court-agrees-to-hear-arguments-in-horrific-1984-dc-murder-case/2016/12/14/050842a4-c24d-11e6-9578-0054287507db_story.html).”

And Brent Kendall of The Wall Street Journal reports that “[Supreme Court to Hear Patent Case That Could Limit Venue Shopping; In case involving Kraft Foods, high court to address rules for where patent cases can be filed](https://t.co/EmuG3lUlPR).”

Posted at [9:54 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69807) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“A Top Defender, Sidelined by the Accused in the Charleston Church Massacre”: In today’s edition of The New York Times, Alan Blinder has [an article](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/13/us/dylann-roof-trial-charleston.html) that begins, “David I. Bruck has spent decades crafting legal strategies to keep people out of the country’s execution chambers. He has argued before the United States Supreme Court on seven occasions, winning six times. He has frustrated prosecutors, challenged judges and softened grim-faced juries.”

Posted at [9:38 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69806) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Top U.S. Court to Consider Curbing Texas Suits by Patent Holders”: Greg Stohr of Bloomberg News has [this report](https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-12-14/top-u-s-court-to-consider-curbing-texas-suits-by-patent-holders).

Andrew Chung of Reuters reports that “[U.S. top court to weigh limits on where patent lawsuits can be filed](http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-kraft-heinz-idUSKBN1432QU).”

And The Associated Press reports that “[Justices to weigh limits on where patent lawsuits are filed](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPREME_COURT_PATENT_LAWSUITS?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).”

This afternoon, the [U.S. Supreme Court](http://www.supremecourt.gov) issued an [Order List](https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121416zr_4h71.pdf) granting review in four cases that will produce three hours of oral argument.

Posted at [8:04 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69805) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Court upholds California’s gun purchase waiting period”: Central Valley Business Times has [this report](http://www.centralvalleybusinesstimes.com/stories/001/?ID=31761) on [a ruling](http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2016/12/14/14-16840.pdf) that the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit](http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov) issued today.

Posted at [1:40 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69804) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Cherokees’ Gay-Marriage Law Is Traditional”: Law professor [Noah Feldman](http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/10257/Feldman) has [this essay](https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-12-14/cherokees-gay-marriage-law-is-traditional) online today at Bloomberg View.

Posted at [1:30 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69803) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“iPhone user can be forced to produce the passcode to his phone, court rules”: Orin Kerr has [this post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2016/12/14/iphone-user-can-be-forced-to-produce-the-passcode-to-his-phone-court-rules/) today at “The Volokh Conspiracy.”

Posted at [1:18 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69802) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Spy Law Could Be Government Tool to Prosecute Press”: Melissa H. Stanzione of Bloomberg Law has [this report](https://bol.bna.com/spy-law-could-be-government-tool-to-prosecute-press/).

Posted at [11:23 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69801) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Should non-lawyer judges be sending people to jail? SCOTUS asked to review.” David Carroll has [this post](http://sixthamendment.org/should-non-lawyer-judges-be-sending-people-to-jail-scotus-asked-to-review/) at the “Pleading the Sixth Blog” of the Sixth Amendment Center. You can view the petition for writ of certiorari [at this link](http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/16-123-petition.pdf).

Posted at [11:18 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69800) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Big Banks Fight to Block Crisis-Era Lawsuits From Continuing”: In today’s edition of The New York Times, Victoria Finkle has [an article](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/13/business/dealbook/big-banks-fight-to-block-crisis-era-lawsuits-from-continuing.html) that begins, “Big banks are fighting tens of billions of dollars of potential legal costs linked to at least a dozen pending lawsuits arising from the financial crisis. Now they want the Supreme Court to weigh in, arguing that regulators took too long to file their claims.”

Posted at [11:07 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69799) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“GM asks Supreme Court to reverse ignition switch claims ruling”: Nate Raymond of Reuters has [this report](http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-gm-idUSKBN1422VN). You can view the petition for writ of certiorari [at this link](http://assets.law360news.com/0868000/868787/gm%20cert%20petition.pdf).

Posted at [11:02 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69798) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore appeals his suspension”: Mike Cason of The Birmingham News has [this report](http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2016/12/alabama_chief_justice_roy_moor_4.html).

Posted at [10:54 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69797) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Erwin Chemerinsky & Joan Biskupic on Donald Trump & the Supreme Court”: [This UCI Law Talks podcast](http://www.law.uci.edu/podcast/episode22.html) was posted online last week.

Posted at [10:45 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/12/14/#69796) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# The 2023 Outside Counsel Rankings: The Top Law Firms According To In-House Counsel
## These are the law firms clients rely on most.
By ABOVE THE LAW  
onJune 13, 2023 at 12:43 PMJune 24, 2023 at 4:10 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/outside-counsel-rankings-top-law-firms/&text=The%202023%20Outside%20Counsel%20Rankings:%20The%20Top%20Law%20Firms%20According%20To%20In-House%20Counsel)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/outside-counsel-rankings-top-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/outside-counsel-rankings-top-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We are pleased to announce the release of our sixth annual ranking of the Top Outside Counsel in partnership with our friends at Lake Whillans. To compile this list of the nation’s top law firms, we turned to the folks who know best — the in-house lawyers who hire them.

ATL’s Outside Counsel Rankings are based not on deal volume, partner profits, or size of firm, but on the aspect most fundamental to a law firm’s business — what their clients think of them. This year, approximately 600 in-house lawyers shared their evaluations of their companies’ outside law firms.

The premise of our survey is simple and direct. We asked two questions: 1) “Which law firms does your company engage for legal services?” and 2) “Please indicate the highest level legal work for which your company will engage the particular firm(s).” The levels of work were defined along a four-point scale:

- Cost-efficient, bulk tasks
- Routine matters
- High-value, complex matters
- “Bet-the-company” matters
The ratings for each firm were averaged and the law firms with the highest average scores made it into our list of the Top Outside Counsel. Check out the results [here](https://abovethelaw.com/top-outside-counsel-rankings-2023/).

[](https://abovethelaw.com/top-outside-counsel-rankings-2023/)

# DLA Piper Says Sexual Assault Accuser 'Orchestrated' Relationship With Former Partner
## The firm has a lot of thought about the allegations.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 30, 2019 at 3:45 PMOctober 31, 2019 at 12:55 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-says-sexual-assault-accuser-orchestrated-relationship-with-former-partner/&text=DLA%20Piper%20Says%20Sexual%20Assault%20Accuser%20‘Orchestrated’%20Relationship%20With%20Former%20Partner)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-says-sexual-assault-accuser-orchestrated-relationship-with-former-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-says-sexual-assault-accuser-orchestrated-relationship-with-former-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Vanina Guerrero

When a Biglaw firm is embroiled in a scandal involving sexual assault allegations, you kinda expect there to be a he said / she said tussle in public. But I’m not sure we expected the wild back and forth that’s gone down in the DLA Piper case that has been rocking the Biglaw world this month.

For those who may not be fluent in all the details, earlier this month, DLA Piper partner Vanina Guerrero released an open letter to the firm, and filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, [alleging that the co-managing partner of the Silicon Valley office, Louis Lehot, repeatedly sexually assaulted her after ](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-accused-of-sexual-assault-by-fellow-partner/)she’d been recruited to the firm in 2018. She asked the firm to release her from their mandatory arbitration agreement so she can pursue her claims in court. The firm has been conspicuously silent on the forced arbitration agreement — despite the [attention their arbitration stance](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/kamala-harris-gets-dragged-into-dla-piper-sexual-assault-controversy/) in this case [has garnered](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/law-school-students-protest-outside-of-dla-piper-over-alleged-sexual-assault/), but, they did announce that Lehot had been [let go from the firm.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-out-amid-sexual-assault-allegations/) But the firm also put Guerrero on [administrative leave](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/now-the-dla-piper-accuser-has-been-put-on-leave/), saying they’d uncovered allegations against her unrelated to Lehot during their investigation of her claims. Lehot[ released a statement](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-accused-of-sexual-assault-speaks-out/) contesting the allegations against him and saying Guerrero was “exploiting” the #MeToo movement. Then a second woman, an anonymous HR manager, came forward with her own allegations against Lehot,[ saying he made her “physically afraid,”](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/second-woman-accuses-former-dla-piper-partner-of-inappropriate-behavior/?rf=1) and further alleging the firm let her go when she complained about Lehot. Then a third women, Leah Christensen, came forward with her own stories of [Lehot’s bullying and name calling.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/third-woman-with-allegations-against-former-dla-piper-partner-says-hes-a-bully-who-called-her-a-dumb-btch/)

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Now, in a newly filed 122-page response to the EEOC, DLA Piper alleges Guerrero “orchestrated” her relationship with Lehot to further her career:

Ms. Guerrero’s own emails show that she was not subject to abuse or assault by Mr. Lehot. In fact, dozens of emails and messages show that Ms. Guerrero was a willing participant in a lengthy emotional flirtation with Mr. Lehot that she orchestrated to advance her career.

As[ noted by Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/10/29/dla-piper-says-partner-orchestrated-relationship-with-her-alleged-assaulter/), DLA Piper’s filing — penned by their attorneys at Gibson Dunn — included a stream of consciousness email Guerrero sent to herself using her DLA account. The email contains ruminations on her relationship with Lehot, containing thoughts like: “Louis: This man will help me / Control him: friendship w/o anything.” And: “Cannelize [sic] the energy – get me to where I need professionally,” and “Don’t open up to him / Leverage it for me…” The firm’s response also calls attention to what Guerrero didn’t say:

The Gibson Dunn attorneys note that the email, which is published in full, includes a number of other candid statements about her professional goals and references to her sexuality, and it does not describe Lehot as “abusive, bullying, or controlling”—in contrast to her EEOC claims.

As further evidence of what it characterizes as Guerrero’s duplicity, the Gibson Dunn team representing DLA Piper pointed to her omission of a March 2019 trip she took with Lehot to Machu Picchu from her EEOC charge and her other public statements.

The trip came after the fourth and final allegation of sexual assault, during which Guerrero claimed she made it clear to Lehot that she would never be in an “intimate relationship” with him, allegedly prompting Lehot to threaten her job, position at the firm and compensation, telling her “their working relationship would never be the same.”

From Pilot and Above The Law  
The firm also counters the allegation Guerrero was retaliated against, saying Lehot and Guerrero disagreed over the optimal place to spend firm resources and the deal she was pulled off of was allegedly at the request of the client.

DLA Piper’s response also took aim at Leah Christensen, the ethics counsel who came forward in support of Guerrero’s claims. The firm says as Christensen was based in another office than Lehot, she wouldn’t know about Lehot’s alleged behavior. Additionally, given Christensen’s role at the firm, DLA Piper says her statements violated ethics rules:

“Christensen’s letter to this Commission, as well as her public statements, are in direct violation of her duty of confidentiality and her duty of loyalty, among other ethical and tortious transgressions,” the letter said.

Unsurprisingly, Guerrero’s attorney, Jeanne Christensen of Wigdor LLP, had something to say about the filing:

“DLA Piper, a global law firm, has managed to reach a new low in the how to smear women that speak out about sexual assault playbook—a low that even Harvey Weinstein, Bill O’Reilly and Matt Lauer did not reach.”

# Celebrating Champions Of Diversity And Inclusion In The Legal Profession
## Congratulations -- and thanks -- to these inspiring leaders of the bar and change agents.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJuly 2, 2019 at 4:16 PMJuly 6, 2019 at 10:17 AM
94
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/celebrating-champions-of-diversity-and-inclusion-in-the-legal-profession/&text=Celebrating%20Champions%20Of%20Diversity%20And%20Inclusion%20In%20The%20Legal%20Profession)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/celebrating-champions-of-diversity-and-inclusion-in-the-legal-profession/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/celebrating-champions-of-diversity-and-inclusion-in-the-legal-profession/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2019/07/2019_NYC_Bar_Diversity_Inclusion_2.jpg)
Juan Arteaga of Crowell & Moring, 2019 Diversity Champion Award Winner. (Photo credit: Alycia Kravitz)

When it comes to diversity and inclusion in the legal profession, there’s good news and bad news. The bad news is that there’s [still so much work to be done](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/um-where-are-all-the-black-partners-at-these-biglaw-firms/). The good news is that the profession is now focused on that work — and leaders of the bar are taking it on.

Last Wednesday, I had the pleasure of attending the [Diversity and Inclusion Celebration Dinner](https://services.nycbar.org/EventDetail?EventKey=DIV062619) of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, where the organization bestowed its Diversity and Inclusion Champion Award upon two such leaders: [Juan Arteaga](https://www.crowell.com/Professionals/Juan-Arteaga), a partner at Crowell & Moring, and [Lisa Linsky](https://www.mwe.com/people/linsky-lisa-a/), a partner at McDermott Will & Emery (and, full disclosure, a longtime friend of mine). It was a beautiful and inspiring event — and it also served as a fundraiser for the [City Bar Fund](https://www.nycbar.org/serving-the-community/city-bar-fund), the Bar’s nonprofit arm that supports the legal profession in advancing social justice (including, but not limited to, diversity efforts).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
After welcoming remarks by [Deborah Martin Owens](https://www.nycbar.org/media-listing/media/detail/deborah-martin-owens-to-lead-diversity-efforts-at-city-bar), Executive Director of Diversity and Inclusion at the City Bar, and [Roger Juan Maldonado](https://www.sgrlaw.com/press-releases/sgr-partner-roger-juan-maldonado-elected-68th-president-of-new-york-city-bar-association/), President of the City Bar, the organization paid tribute to Justice [Rosalyn Richter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosalyn_Richter) of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, First Department. Two members of the Committee to Enhance Diversity in the Profession, [Kathy Hirata Chin](https://www.crowell.com/Professionals/Kathy-Hirata-Chin) of Crowell & Moring and [Matthew Morningstar](https://www.linkedin.com/in/matt-morningstar-5162084/) of Morgan Stanley, praised Justice Richter, outgoing co-chair of the Committee, for her tireless efforts to advance diversity in the profession. They noted that the past year has been a difficult one for Justice Richter — in September, she lost her wife, LGBTQ activist [Janet Weinberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janet_Weinberg) — but Justice Richter continued to work hard for the causes she cares about, including LGBTQ rights, diversifying the judiciary, and educating young people about law and the legal system.

Amid a standing ovation, Justice Richter took the stage. When she reached the podium, she joked about how long it took to make it up there in her walker — and thanked the City Bar for having a ramp leading up to the stage, without her even having to ask for it.

“I have the privilege of being an appellate judge, and so I now have the privilege of asking for things I was too scared to ask for as a young lawyer,” Justice Richter said. “We as a legal community need to stop having inaccessible events.”

[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2019/07/2019_NYC_Bar_Diversity_Inclusion_1.jpg)
Left to right: Benson Cohen of Sidley Austin, Co-Chair of the Diversity & Inclusion Champion Award Committee; Matthew Morningstar of Morgan Stanley, Incoming Co-Chair of the Enhance Diversity in the Profession Committee; Lisa Linsky of McDermott Will & Emery, 2019 Diversity Champion Award Winner; Kathy Chin of Crowell & Moring, Co-Chair of the Enhance Diversity in the Profession Committee; Juan Arteaga of Crowell & Moring, 2019 Diversity Champion Award Winner; Roger Juan Maldonado of Smith, Gambrell & Russell, President of the City Bar; Bret Parker, Executive Director of the City Bar; and Justice Rosalyn Richter of the First Department, Outgoing Co-Chair of the Enhance Diversity in the Profession Committee. (Photo credit: Alycia Kravitz)

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Following presentations about the City Bar’s various [pipeline programs](https://www.nycbar.org/serving-the-community/diversity-and-inclusion/student-pipeline-programs) devoted to advancing diversity, the 2019 Diversity and Inclusion Champion Award was presented to — and enthusiastically accepted by — Juan Arteaga and Lisa Linsky. Both delivered heartfelt and eloquent remarks focused on different aspects of diversity and inclusion.

Arteaga focused on immigration. He has done extensive pro bono work in the field, representing immigrants, including battered women and their children, in immigration and deportation proceedings. He told the story of one such case.

In 2017, he was asked to help a family of undocumented immigrants from Colombia who are now living in the United States. The oldest son applied for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, while the family pursued asylum claims.

The son received notification that he needed to be fingerprinted as part of the DACA application process — and he was terrified, afraid that the fingerprinting could result in him being taken into custody and deported. After much discussion and deliberation with his family, the son decided to go in for the fingerprinting. Arteaga accompanied him on that day.

On the day of the appointment, the son hugged his father in a parking lot a few blocks away from the fingerprinting site (because his father was not joining his son for that appointment, and understandably so). The son was shaking with fear as he hugged his father and told him how much he loved him. Neither father nor son was certain that the son wouldn’t be taken into custody for eventual deportation when he went in for the fingerprinting.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
In the end, the son, accompanied by Juan Arteaga, had his fingerprints taken without incident. But the more Arteaga reflected on the episode, the more sad and angry he became. Immigrants shouldn’t have to live in such fear — and they shouldn’t have to endure the deplorable conditions and treatment at the border that have dominated the headlines as of late.

When it comes to immigration, Arteaga said, “We need to advocate for the values and principles that brought us here this evening. Our resolution of the immigration debate will determine the kind of nation we become.”

[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2019/07/2019_NYC_Bar_Diversity_Inclusion_3.jpg)
Lisa Linsky of McDermott Will & Emery, 2019 Diversity Champion Award Winner. (Photo credit: Alycia Kravitz)

In her acceptance speech, Lisa Linsky focused on LGBTQ rights — appropriately enough, given that the dinner took place just a few days before the 50th anniversary of the [Stonewall riots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stonewall_riots) and the [WorldPride celebration](https://2019-worldpride-stonewall50.nycpride.org/history-news/a-global-celebration-arrives-in-new-york/) in New York. She talked about her work at McDermott as the first partner-in-charge of Firmwide Diversity and partner-in-charge of LGBT Diversity and Inclusion — which she viewed as of a piece with the work she did in the Westchester County District Attorney’s Office, as a prosecutor focused on sex crimes and child abuse. The common thread: advocating for people whose voices were not being heard.

Linsky did point out the progress made on LGBTQ equality in recent years. She noted that the dinner was taking place on a momentous date: June 26, the anniversary of both United States v. Windsor (2013), in which the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act, and Obergefell v. Hodges (2015), in which the Court ruled in favor of nationwide marriage equality.

But she also urged everyone not to become complacent. Just as electing an African-American president didn’t mark the end of racism, the advent of marriage equality didn’t mark the end of discrimination against the LGBTQ community. Instead, Linsky said, “We must continuing naming — and resisting — the ways in which people continue to be excluded and oppressed.”

The evening concluded with remarks from [Letitia “Tish” James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letitia_James), the 67th Attorney General of the State of New York, as well as the first African-American and first woman to be elected to the position. She began by invoking the now-infamous AP [photograph](https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/26/reader-center/rio-grande-migrants-photo.html) of two migrants, a father and his young daughter, who drowned in the Rio Grande while trying to enter the United States.

“Caging individuals and separating families is not an immigration policy,” she said. “It is man’s inhumanity to man.”

James then turned to the Census case, [Department of Commerce v. New York](https://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/department-of-commerce-v-new-york/) — which her office litigated, and which the Supreme Court was going to rule on the next day.

“Let’s hope the justices get it right,” she said. “Let’s hope they recognize the proposition that in this country, everyone should be counted.”

[Diversity and Inclusion Celebration Dinner](https://services.nycbar.org/EventDetail?EventKey=DIV062619) [New York City Bar Association]

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/), the founding editor of Above the Law, is a [writer](https://davidlat.com/writing/), [speaker](https://davidlat.com/speaking/), and [legal recruiter at Lateral Link](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/team/david-lat/), where he is a managing director in the New York office. David’s book, [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/SupremeAmbitions) (2014), was described by the New York Times as “the most buzzed-about novel of the year” among legal elites. David previously worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

# Biglaw Firm Hits The Mark With Individualized Bonuses
## The feedback has been universally positive -- so far.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 20, 2016 at 1:18 PMDecember 20, 2016 at 1:22 PM
3
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-hits-the-mark-with-individualized-bonuses/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Hits%20The%20Mark%20With%20Individualized%20Bonuses)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-hits-the-mark-with-individualized-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-hits-the-mark-with-individualized-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Individualized bonuses are always a bit of a mixed bag. Sometimes associates are happy — even beating the market standard — and other times the lack of transparency come bonus time is designed to lowball associates. But the reports we are getting out of Sidley Austin seem to be glowing.

On Friday, the firm gave word that the annual bonuses were on their way, and now we are getting feedback based on those numbers. So far, it has been universally positive.



[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Our tipsters’ paydays have ranged from market levels to above market, setting up a very happy holiday indeed:

I’m pleased it’s market. Rumor was it wasn’t going to be market until the
AT&T merger.

Everyone I know is pleased, at or above market (for higher billers)

Sidley associate reporting in… got market bonus in LA with about
2100 hours

I billed well over the minimum for bonus (2400+) and got $10k over market.

[R]eceived full Cravath scale despite some extenuating circumstances that caused me to miss hours. Very happy.

So, Sidley attorneys, is everyone as happy as our assortment of tipsters? Feel free to sound off [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). All complaints (or additional praise) will be kept anonymous — and could find its way into an update to this story.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Incoming Biglaw Associates Need To Know: Do They Still Have Jobs?
## Let's hope not...
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 26, 2020 at 2:40 PMAugust 26, 2020 at 2:27 PM
45
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/incoming-biglaw-associates-need-to-know-do-they-still-have-jobs/&text=Incoming%20Biglaw%20Associates%20Need%20To%20Know:%20Do%20They%20Still%20Have%20Jobs?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/incoming-biglaw-associates-need-to-know-do-they-still-have-jobs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/incoming-biglaw-associates-need-to-know-do-they-still-have-jobs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

The coronavirus crisis has wreaked havoc upon the legal profession, leading some firms to cut salaries, furlough employees, and even conduct layoffs. Several months have now passed, and many firms have started to partially or completely roll back their austerity measures. But what happens if things get worse?

What if things go the way they did during the last recession? Will incoming first-year associates suddenly find themselves without jobs? Will offers be rescinded like they were in 2009?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
This is the question that’s on everyone’s minds, considering start dates have already been deferred. With worries abound, industry observers are here to offer some support and some calming words of comfort. They don’t think there’s anything for first-year associates to worry about; the chances of a 2009 repeat performance are “extremely remote.” From the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/08/25/what-are-the-chances-of-first-year-associate-cancellations/):

“Those were different times. I’m not seeing that firms are in that kind of financial distress,” said Joan Newman, an executive coach at Joan Newman & Associates, who works with big-firm partners and senior associates.

“Some areas are busier than others, but it’s not all gloom and doom like it was in 2009,” said Newman, who worked with laid-off Big Law associates in 2009 to find other positions. “M&A is down but litigation is starting back up again and labor and employment law is booming.”

A leader of a national law firm echoed these thoughts, saying “it’s highly unlikely that anyone will further push back deferrals or cut the class.”

Some incoming Biglaw associates may have reason to be concerned — they’ve heard nothing from their firms regarding their start dates. Is something like this going on at your firm? Please get in touch with us via email or text — [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) or (646) 820-8477) — and we’ll try to get to the bottom of it for you.

Keep your fingers crossed that nothing changes. We’d hate to see yet another lost generation of lawyers left behind by Biglaw.

# Someone Thinks This Biglaw Partner Should Be Thrown In Jail
## Why don't you tell us how you really feel?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 22, 2016 at 3:00 PMDecember 22, 2016 at 12:50 PM
2
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/someone-thinks-this-biglaw-partner-should-be-thrown-in-jail/&text=Someone%20Thinks%20This%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Should%20Be%20Thrown%20In%20Jail)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/someone-thinks-this-biglaw-partner-should-be-thrown-in-jail/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/someone-thinks-this-biglaw-partner-should-be-thrown-in-jail/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

David Kramer

I hope they take his law license and throw him in jail.

— Stephen C. Sieber, president of Song Fi, [speaking with Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/875309/google-atty-s-shouting-match-prompts-removal-bid) about Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati partner [David Kramer](https://www.wsgr.com/WSGR/DBIndex.aspx?SectionName=attorneys/BIOS/2736.htm). Sieber’s company is suing Google, represented by Kramer and WSGR. Sieber alleges he had a verbal altercation with Kramer before a hearing in which Kramer called him a “scumbag” and was “highly arrogant and insulting” and refused to shake hands with him. Song Fi has asked the court to remove Kramer from the case. A Wilson Sonsini rep has said the motion for sanctions is baseless.

# Biglaw Circles The Wagons, Say One Of Their Own Doesn't Deserve Jail Time Despite Felony Conviction
## His lawyers argue he's been punished enough.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 18, 2018 at 3:55 PMJuly 18, 2018 at 3:35 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/biglaw-circles-the-wagons-say-one-of-their-own-doesnt-deserve-jail-time-despite-felony-conviction/&text=Biglaw%20Circles%20The%20Wagons,%20Say%20One%20Of%20Their%20Own%20Doesn’t%20Deserve%20Jail%20Time%20Despite%20Felony%20Conviction)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/biglaw-circles-the-wagons-say-one-of-their-own-doesnt-deserve-jail-time-despite-felony-conviction/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/biglaw-circles-the-wagons-say-one-of-their-own-doesnt-deserve-jail-time-despite-felony-conviction/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Evan Greebel and Martin Shkreli

If you’re the type of person who keeps up with Biglaw gossip, then you’ve surely heard the name [Evan Greebel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/evan-greebel/) before. He’s the former partner at both Katten Muchin — where he worked for more than a decade — and Kaye Scholer who was convicted of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The conviction stems from his work with infamous pharma bro, Martin Shkreli. Greebel was outside counsel for pharmaceutical company Retrophin from 2012 to 2014. During that time, prosecutors alleged Greebel assisted Shkreli in using Retrophin’s assets to pay investors in unrelated hedge funds run by Shkreli through the use of phony settlement and consulting agreements and fraudulently backdating agreements.

Now sentencing time is rolling around — scheduled for August 9th — and Greebel faces [up to 20 years in prison](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/former-biglaw-partner-faces-up-to-20-years-in-prison-for-fraudulent-scheme/?rf=1). But his lawyers — he’s repped by Gibson Dunn — have submitted a sentencing memo asking Judge Kiyo Matsumoto for no jail time. Attached to the memo are some 180 letters asking for leniency, and quite a few from Greebel’s former Biglaw partners.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
One such former partner, Murray Schwartz, now a partner at Warshaw Burstein and a former village justice in New York, [as reported by Law.com](https://www.law.com/2018/07/17/evan-greebel-shouldnt-go-to-jail-his-former-law-partners-say/) laid the blame for Greebel’s legal woes at Shkreli’s feet, not an [unfamiliar strategy for the defense](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/ex-biglaw-partner-and-former-client-go-at-it-in-criminal-case/):

“Evan Greebel had a terrible encounter with the devil incarnate and sadly the devil often wins,” Schwartz wrote, apparently referring to Greebel’s ties to Shkreli. “As a sitting judge, I used to divide mentally those defendants who would hurt someone from those that would not. Evan will not hurt a soul.”

Troy Foster, partner at Perkins Coie and former colleague of Greebel’s, agrees the pharma bro should shoulder the responsibility:

“I know well the pressures to perform in the setting of a large private law firm,” said Foster, who was a summer associate with Greebel at Fried Frank. “We have to trust that our partners in specialized practice areas are giving sound guidance. … And, most importantly we need to trust our clients to give us accurate information and conduct themselves in accordance with the standards of basic decency. Evan’s client apparently failed on every count, and the resulting fiasco swept Evan up into this case.”

While Elan Keller, a former partner of Greebel who is now at Reed Smith,  pointed to past instances of Greebel’s legal ethics to argue he shouldn’t serve any time in jail:

Keller, in his own letter, explained that Greebel turned down a prospective client proposing a tax structure that wouldn’t pass muster. “Evan showed professional responsibility and integrity (and a lack of disappointment) even when faced with losing out on getting credit and attribution for substantial fees from a prospective client,” Keller said.

His lawyers pointed to Greebel’s “shattered” career and life — he’s been disbarred and is unlikely to be able to practice law again — as well as his “dire” financial straights to contend that he’s been adequately punished and should not serve jail time:

But unemployed since 2016 and tasked with mounting a defense in a criminal trial, “his financial situation is—and will likely remain—dire,” his attorneys said, noting a presentencing report that said he has “a contingent liability of several million dollars to the insurance company which paid for his legal defense.”

If only all non-violent offenders were able to mount such compelling arguments against their incarceration.

# NY To $180K: Another Big New York Firm Matches Cravath
## When it rains cash in Biglaw, it pours! Another large New York firm has matched the Cravath scale.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 7, 2016 at 1:14 PMJune 7, 2016 at 3:16 PM
14
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-another-big-new-york-firm-matches-cravath/&text=NY%20To%20$180K:%20Another%20Big%20New%20York%20Firm%20Matches%20Cravath)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-another-big-new-york-firm-matches-cravath/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-another-big-new-york-firm-matches-cravath/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When cash begins to rain down from the heavens above Biglaw firms, it always pours. More firms are falling in line with the new Cravath salary scale. Earlier today, we saw our first [major match from Milbank Tweed](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-first-major-match/), and now another New York powerhouse has anted up beaucoup bucks for its associates.

Paul Weiss, a firm with almost one thousand lawyers and more than $1 billion in annual revenue, has matched the [Cravath salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/?rf=1).

This isn’t surprising news. During Biglaw’s last bonus season, Paul Weiss matched Cravath [within three hours](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-a-second-firm-falls-in-line/). In fact, according to a source, Brad Karp, the firm’s managing partner, said Paul Weiss [will always match market](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-a-second-firm-falls-in-line/), but never set it. In his [memo to associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-another-big-new-york-firm-matches-cravath/2/), Karp said the move was “in keeping with our commitment that the compensation of our attorneys be at the top of the market.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Here’s something worth noting: incoming members of the Paul Weiss class of 2016 are also being bumped up to the $180K salary scale. That’s great news for recent law school graduates with loads of debt that needs to be paid off. How exciting!

Congrats to all Paul Weiss associates on your brand new salaries!

UPDATE (3:00 p.m.): A tipster points out that Paul Weiss is technically beating the market, at least for the classes of 2007 and beyond. Note that in the memo provided on the next page that Paul Weiss provides an extra $10,000 to lawyers in years 2007 and senior, for a salary of $325,000. We acknowledge that compensation for the classes of 2007 and senior is discretionary at most firms, but we can’t help but wonder if other firms will state a salary figure for these classes as well in future Cravath matches.

[Milbank Matches Cravath Associate Pay Boost](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202759474944/Milbank-Matches-Cravath-Associate-Pay-Boost?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL) [Am Law Daily]

# Biglaw's Starting A Talent War In Miami
## The lateral market is heating up in the Magic City.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 27, 2022 at 2:57 PMJuly 27, 2022 at 1:05 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/biglaws-starting-a-talent-war-in-miami/&text=Biglaw’s%20Starting%20A%20Talent%20War%20In%20Miami)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/biglaws-starting-a-talent-war-in-miami/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/biglaws-starting-a-talent-war-in-miami/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


“We’re starting to see a flight to quality. We have a new breed of firms in Miami, and you always want to play for the Yankees. If you have an opportunity to move up the food chain, a lot of people want to take that.”

— Florida legal recruiter Josh Dull [spoke to Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/miamis-new-breed-of-law-firms-spurs-fresh-recruiting-battle) about the booming Miami legal market. A number of Biglaw firms — Quinn Emanuel, Kirkland, Sidley, King & Spalding, Winston & Strawn — have all recently decided to expand their footprints in the city. These mega players in the market are luring talent away from local firms and a talent war is afoot. He continued, “I don’t think Miami will ever replace Wall Street. That’s ludicrous for anyone to think. But companies are moving here; talent’s moving here. It’s going to be fun to watch.”

# Am Law 50 Firm Lays Off 4 Percent Of Its Global Workforce
## That's more than 100 lawyers and staff.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 9, 2020 at 11:17 AM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/am-law-50-firm-lays-off-4-percent-of-its-global-workforce/&text=Am%20Law%2050%20Firm%20Lays%20Off%204%20Percent%20Of%20Its%20Global%20Workforce)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/am-law-50-firm-lays-off-4-percent-of-its-global-workforce/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/am-law-50-firm-lays-off-4-percent-of-its-global-workforce/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As with all things in Biglaw as of late, with good news tends to come some pretty godawful news. As firms work to become leaner through these tough times, lawyers and staff members may unexpectedly find themselves on the unemployment line. Hot on the heels of announcing the [reversal of its COVID-19 austerity measures](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/am-law-50-firm-completely-reverses-its-pay-cuts-announces-some-bonus-news/), news of Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner’s global layoffs has come to light.

As part of a business review called “Project Advance,” Bryan Cave has not only reorganized and combined some of its practice groups and appointed leaders for its three new primary global businesses (corporate and finance transactions; real estate; litigation and investigations), but the firm has also conducted a swath of layoffs. As reported by Law.com International, BCLP has laid off about 4 percent of its global workforce — which means that an estimated 118 lawyers and staff have been let go.

BCLP co-chairs Lisa Mayhew and Steve Baumer said in the statement: “Project Advance will further transform and elevate how we serve our clients, laying the foundation for our next phase of growth internationally. This is a multi-year strategy to further extend BCLP’s leadership around real estate as an asset class, corporate and finance transactions, and litigation and investigations, where we see significant growth opportunities for BCLP.”

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Best of luck to all those who are affected by the layoffs at Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Top 25 Biglaw Firm Offers Bonus-Eligible Diversity & Inclusion Billable Hours
## The firm has been successfully running this program for almost a year.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 8, 2021 at 1:48 PMFebruary 11, 2021 at 10:15 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-25-biglaw-firm-offers-bonus-eligible-diversity-inclusion-billable-hours/&text=Top%2025%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Offers%20Bonus-Eligible%20Diversity%20&%20Inclusion%20Billable%20Hours)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-25-biglaw-firm-offers-bonus-eligible-diversity-inclusion-billable-hours/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-25-biglaw-firm-offers-bonus-eligible-diversity-inclusion-billable-hours/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms continue to roll out worthy initiatives when it comes to showing just how important diversity and inclusion are to the future of the legal profession. We’ve previously acknowledged [Dorsey & Whitney](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/biglaw-firm-introduces-diversity-hours-that-count-toward-associate-billable-requirements/), [Hogan Lovells](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/care-about-biglaw-diversity-well-now-you-can-bill-for-it/), and [Reed Smith](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-offer-billable-diversity-hours-for-all-timekeepers/) as firms where approved diversity and inclusion-related work will be billable for attorneys and will count toward bonus thresholds. We’ve just received word that another leading law firm has had a successful program like this that’s been operating quietly under the radar for almost a year, but now it’s time time to show them some praise.

Cooley — the firm that introduced [special appreciation bonuses for associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cooley-bonuses/) and sits at #23 in the latest Am Law 100 rankings — rolled out its diversity and inclusion billable hours credit program on February 21, 2020 in a memo to all associates, technical advisors, and patent agents. Anyone working in one of those roles at the firm will receive up to 50 hours of billable credit for qualified activities that will count toward their productivity and bonus eligibility.

Here are the broad categories that are eligible for D&I billable credit at Cooley:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
• Diversity committee and women’s initiative leadership – time spent carrying out responsibilities of committee leaders

• Affinity group leadership – time spent carrying out responsibilities of affinity group leadership, including drafting communications, planning events, leading calls and running initiatives

• Internal diversity mentoring and sponsorship – participation in formal Cooley diversity mentorship programs, including affinity group pairings, reverse mentoring, leave liaisons and sponsorship programs

• Law school relationships – representing the firm at law school diversity events and job fairs, participating in minority student organization panels and events and mentoring underrepresented law students

• Pipeline and closing efforts – outreach before or after a diverse candidate interview in an effort to attract them to Cooley, time spent managing the 1L Diversity Fellowship pipeline, and establishing recruiting relationships with candidates of diverse backgrounds

• Client partnerships – participation in client diversity programs, including Google’s diversity mentor program

• Other activities approved in advance by the director of diversity & inclusion

Congratulations to Cooley on its commitment to diversity, and for offering its attorneys and other timekeepers a way to create a more inclusive workplace.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# That Special Time Of Year Where We All Remember How To Spell 'Bockius'
## Third name on the letterhead blues...
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 5, 2022 at 5:14 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/morgan-lewis-2022-bonuses/&text=That%20Special%20Time%20Of%20Year%20Where%20We%20All%20Remember%20How%20To%20Spell%20‘Bockius’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/morgan-lewis-2022-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/morgan-lewis-2022-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When I had my campus interview with Morgan Lewis, the interviewer asked me to spell “Bockius.” Didn’t see that one coming.

There’s a certain tragedy in being too far down the letterhead. After a career working your way all the the way to seeing your name on the door, you’re usually doomed by marketing to become the answer to a trivia question. For the record, Morris Rex Bockius joined the firm as a first-year associate in 1883 and ultimately ran the joint until 1939. So let’s put the appropriate respect on that.

Anyway, Morgan Lewis… and Bockius announced bonuses on Friday. The number 10 ranked Am Law firm with $2,577,700,000 in gross revenue last year delivers the news via voicemail as opposed to memo, but we’ve been informed that it is matching the market as defined by peer firms. So…

 

Class	Bonus
Class of 2022	$15K (pro-rated)
Class of 2021	$20K
Class of 2020	$30K
Class of 2019	$57.5K
Class of 2018	$75K
Class of 2017	$90K
Class of 2016	$105K
Given the lack of a memo, it’s not clear if the firm is joining the clutch of firms offering $115K to the class of 2015 and senior or if those folks will be getting individualized bonuses. We’ll update as we get that nailed down.

The firm requires associates post 1900+ billable hours with an additional caveat that 20 of which had to be pro bono hours. Bonuses will be paid on January 31, 2023.

Congrats on making Morris Bockius proud.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.
